author: Rob Stock
title: Planning the finances for the big OE
text:
Planning the finances for the big OE ROB STOCK Last updated 13:27, July 28 2015 123RF 
Just make sure that backpack has a travel insurance policy inside it. OPINION: 
The big OE is the Kiwi middle class' right of passage, the chance to see the far-away world and conclude that there's no place like home. 
It once felt easy to just up sticks and head off with a backpack stuffed with undies and a heart filled with wanderlust. 
It is a life opportunity that offers so much. I myself still count the year and a bit I spent in Latin America as the making of me. 
Like many things in life, it has been complicated by politicians determined that young people must suffer the consequences of their own actions. 
A big OE needs a lot of planning, and as young people are not always inclined to careful planning, I am writing this column for their parents and grandparents, who have an interest in mitigating some of the risks youngsters need to take seriously before heading off. 
Now when I headed off, I didn't even have a credit card, let alone any credit card debt to service and it was before anybody had enormous student loans. I also didn't take travel insurance. 
In short, I was a ruddy idiot, and had disaster struck, it would have been my poor parents who would have faced digging deep to bail me out. 
Remember that song Send lawyers, guns and money? That pretty much encapsulates the plan in a worst-case scenario. 
Here's the planning list: 
If you can't afford travel insurance, you can't afford to travel. 
In the middle of last year one Kiwi got run over in Mexico. 
Long story short: nasty fractures, air ambulance to LA, hospital stay, flown home. 
Southern Cross Travel Insurance paid the $167,000 bill. 
Appendicitis in the US. The bill was $76,5000. That happened too. 
I was bullet-proof at 21. I did several things that I look back on now with utter bemusement. One at least, I am sure, left a permanent mark on my kidneys. Carry the emergency contact number for the insurer with you at all times while abroad. 
Read the policy. Know what it covers. Know the "exceptions"- the things it will not pay for. 
Student debt: 
If you're going overseas for 183 consecutive days or less (about six months), you're still considered to be a New Zealand-based borrower and you don't have to do anything. 
That means no repayments, if you are not earning, and no interest mounting up. 
But, if you're going overseas for longer, you'll be considered an overseas-based borrower. And, that means you have to make payments, and you are charged interest (currently 5.3 per cent on your debt. If you do not make payments, you get charged penalty interest on the missed payments, which is 9.3 per cent. 
Your debt could spiral up, if you are caught. Immigration gives data to the Inland Revenue (IRD), so there's a good chance that'll happen. 
The good news is that you can apply for a "repayment holiday" with the Inland Revenue Department. If granted, there will be no interest and no payments to make for up to a year. 
That was designed with OEs in mind. If you are earning while overseas, at least there are fee-free deals with the likes of Western Union to help you make payments. 
Bone up on the IRD website page on going overseas . 
Your money system: 
You need to devise yourself a money system when heading overseas. How will you pay for things? How will you carry funds? 
I became a cash economy in Latin America, which worked pretty well as I was based in one city, working away. 
The supermarket, the landlord, the bar tabs - everybody got paid in cash. 
I had no need to do cross-border transacting, which was just as well because back then I probably didn't even know that Western Union existed. 
Mine was a bad system, not set up in any way to give me access to emergency cash to get me out of a fix. 
These days, your money system will probably involve a debit card. 
In the old days, taking money overseas meant travellers' cheques in your sock. These days it is going to be an international debit card from your bank, preloaded with spending money, and able to be reloaded online with a transfer from another account, or in a branch by either you, or your folks. 
You can even preload some of them with the currency of the country, or countries to which you are heading. New Zealand has a volatile currency, and that gives you the chance to lock in an exchange rate you like before you go. 
These debit cards are now offered by all banks. They run off the Visa and Mastercard systems, which means they are accepted all over the world. 
They are also blockable, and replaceable, if stolen. And they are PIN-protected. 
Emergency funds: 
Only so much can be asked of the Banco de Mum and Dad. 
A credit card with a line of credit on it can also form a part of your plans, but it also brings a big temptation and once drawn down on, minimum payments have to be made. Make sure your bank knows your plans. 
Other debts: 
Personal debt is a stone around your neck. It is to be avoided. Overdrafts at the bank, personal loans and credit cards are hurdles to heading overseas. 
It is tempting to head off overseas while leaving debt here, perhaps to pay them from income earned overseas. Making debt repayments from overseas earnings is possible, but it is costly, and if exchange rates move against you, it can get even more costly. 
Running New Zealand accounts from overseas is possible nowadays thanks to the internet, but be jolly careful what devices you use to access accounts, and do not trust overseas free wi-fi. It often isn't safe. 
If humanly possible, deal to the debt before you go. 
Actually taking on a debt to pay for the trip is a bad idea. The more debt you have, the greater the risk you carry, and the further away from ever owning a house you are. 
What you do on the OE: 
Give this some thought. 
My Latin American experience gave my CV a kick-start, which helped when it was over. I was an English teacher there. Solid work experience. My first out of university. 
Costly wandering has its attractions over one-place working. 
Both have a value, but working is much easier to talk to prospective employers about. 
If you are sufficiently well-educated, you can even land jobs overseas straight out of university. Law grads often end up getting snapped up by London law-firms, for example. 
Make use of family connections and any right to work overseas that you may have by dint of having that overseas passport. 
Another option is to get overseas by volunteering, which usually involves you having to do a bit of charity fund-raising beforehand. 
There are some inspiring stories to be told on volunteering. Here's Olivia Benton-Guy's , which I stumbled on just this week. - Stuff
